repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: There was a discussion earlier at https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31249#discussion_r1849409391. I am not very supportive of renaming `vim.lsp.Client.offset_encoding` to `vim.lsp.Client.position_encoding`(which would be a breaking change unlike the others), but I have completed it and placed it in a separate commit for easier review and revert.

comment_data.body: Let's do non-breaking changes such as this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -326,10 +326,10 @@ end
 ---@param lines string[]
 ---@param start_range vim.lsp.sync.Range
 ---@param end_range vim.lsp.sync.Range
----@param offset_encoding string
+---@param position_encoding string
 ---@param line_ending string
 ---@return integer
-local function compute_range_length(lines, start_range, end_range, offset_encoding, line_ending)
+local function compute_range_length(lines, start_range, end_range, position_encoding, line_ending)

comment_data.body: Keep this change also, especially since it's a description and not a literal parameter name. But even here, the parameter name can be renamed because it's non-breaking.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -904,17 +904,20 @@ end
 --- Shows document and optionally jumps to the location.
 ---
 ---@param location lsp.Location|lsp.LocationLink
----@param offset_encoding 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'?
+---@param position_encoding 'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'?
 ---@param opts? vim.lsp.util.show_document.Opts
 ---@return boolean `true` if succeeded
-function M.show_document(location, offset_encoding, opts)
+function M.show_document(location, position_encoding, opts)
   -- location may be Location or LocationLink
   local uri = location.uri or location.targetUri
   if uri == nil then
     return false
   end
-  if offset_encoding == nil then
-    vim.notify_once('show_document must be called with valid offset encoding', vim.log.levels.WARN)
+  if position_encoding == nil then
+    vim.notify_once(
+      'show_document must be called with valid position encoding',

comment_data.body:
Also in favor of local renames like this.
```suggestion
    local position_encoding = client and client.offset_encoding or 'utf-16'
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,11 +78,11 @@ local function query_workspace_symbols(pattern)
   local results = {}
   for client_id, responses in pairs(assert(results_by_client)) do
     local client = lsp.get_client_by_id(client_id)
-    local offset_encoding = client and client.offset_encoding or 'utf-16'
+    local position_encoding = client and client.position_encoding or 'utf-16'

comment_data.body: This is non-breaking. We can keep this change. Similar for the others.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2138,17 +2139,17 @@ rename({old_fname}, {new_fname}, {opts})               *vim.lsp.util.rename()*
                      • {ignoreIfExists}? (`boolean`)
 
                                                 *vim.lsp.util.show_document()*
-show_document({location}, {offset_encoding}, {opts})
+show_document({location}, {position_encoding}, {opts})
     Shows document and optionally jumps to the location.
 
     Parameters: ~
-      • {location}         (`lsp.Location|lsp.LocationLink`)
-      • {offset_encoding}  (`'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'?`)
-      • {opts}             (`table?`) A table with the following fields:
-                           • {reuse_win}? (`boolean`) Jump to existing window
-                             if buffer is already open.
-                           • {focus}? (`boolean`) Whether to focus/jump to
-                             location if possible. (defaults: true)
+      • {location}           (`lsp.Location|lsp.LocationLink`)
+      • {position_encoding}  (`'utf-8'|'utf-16'|'utf-32'?`)

comment_data.body:
Since this is breaking, we don't need to make this change. Instead, as a bridge, let's just mention "position encoding" in the docs so that it can be found by searching, and to help users understand that `offset_encoding` is an alias to the spec's "position encoding".
```suggestion
      • {offset_encoding}     (`string`) Called "position encoding" in LSP spec. The encoding used for communicating
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -904,7 +904,7 @@ Lua module: vim.lsp.client                                        *lsp-client*
       • {rpc}                   (`vim.lsp.rpc.PublicClient`) RPC client
                                 object, for low level interaction with the
                                 client. See |vim.lsp.rpc.start()|.
-      • {offset_encoding}       (`string`) The encoding used for communicating
+      • {position_encoding}     (`string`) The encoding used for communicating

comment_data.body: nit: line length limit is 100 chars... why is this crunched up?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -148,8 +149,10 @@ local validate = vim.validate
 --- See |vim.lsp.rpc.start()|.
 --- @field rpc vim.lsp.rpc.PublicClient
 ---
---- The encoding used for communicating with the server. You can modify this in
---- the `config`'s `on_init` method before text is sent to the server.
+--- Called "position encoding" in LSP spec,
+--- the encoding used for communicating with the server.
+--- You can modify this in the `config`'s `on_init` method
+--- before text is sent to the server.

comment_regular_data.body: Thoughts on deprecating `offset_encoding` before fully removing it?

Considering that `offset_encoding` mostly appears in positional parameters, I think it's more of a documentation change? The real refactoring and breaking change are the fields in `vim.lsp.Client` (or `vim.lsp.CTGroup`, but it is an internal module and can be changed safely). I did not completely remove it but used `vim.deprecate`, and whether this change should be completed is still up for discussion. It is merely a renaming, yet it is a breaking change.

> Considering that `offset_encoding` mostly appears in positional parameters, I think it's more of a documentation change? The real refactoring and breaking change are the fields in `vim.lsp.Client` (or `vim.lsp.CTGroup`, but it is an internal module and can be changed safely). I did not completely remove it but used `vim.deprecate`, and whether this change should be completed is still up for discussion. It is merely a renaming, yet it is a breaking change.

I see. I agree with @justinmk that consistency with the spec terminology is nice, but I want to better understand @mfussenegger's [comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31249#discussion_r1851051599). @mfussenegger: Are you also in favour of this rename?

To me it's not really worth it.

If some feel strongly about this I won't object but it would need to bump the deprecation removal to `0.13` instead of `0.12`.
Otherwise users will get a deprecation on nightly once this is merged - and plugins are forced to add a compat layer on every use if they want to stay warning-free with both 0.10 and nightly - that's tedious.

I kinda feel as if having mixed naming is more confusing than just sticking to the different name. 

Are we sure this is an improvement?

> I kinda feel as if having mixed naming is more confusing than just sticking to the different name.

There is only one place AFAIK where the old name is still used, and its doc mentions "position encoding". That seems pretty limited to me.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

labels.description: changes that are not features or bugfixes
labels.name: refactor

title: refactor(lsp): rename `offset_encoding` to `position_encoding`
